lead_paragraph: College admissions officers have long used advanced-placement courses as an important tool for measuring applicants and the high schools they attend. But today, in a lawsuit filed in a state court here, the American Civil Liberties Union of Southern California said that yardstick was just another way of discriminating against students and schools in low-income and minority neighborhoods. The suit, against the State of California, says these schools offer far fewer advanced courses than those in other communities. Beverly Hills High, for example, a mostly white school, offers 14 advanced placement courses, the suit says, while Inglewood High in South Los Angeles, mainly black and Hispanic, has only 3.
abstract: American Civil Liberties Union, in suit filed against State of California, contends that advanced-placement courses used by college admission officers for measuring applicants is just another way of discriminating against students and schools in low-income and minority neighborhoods (M)

headline.main: Suit Says Advanced-Placement Classes Show Bias
